newsitem.title: UK: IPE Brent stable at lower levels on Iraq, IEA news.
newsitem.headline: IPE Brent stable at lower levels on Iraq, IEA news.

text.p: IPE Brent crude oil were stable at slightly lower levels on Tuesday following bearish reports from Iraq and the International Energy Agency (IEA,) traders said.

August Brent was trading at $18.12 a barrel at 1224 GMT, a fall of seven cents from Monday's close. July gas oil was $1.25 firmer at $162.50 and traders said its rise was a catch-up with Brent, which rallied strongly on Monday after the gas oil market closed.
"It is very neutral," one broker said. "We are within yesterday's range and that was more or less in Friday's range."
Prices dipped initially on Tuesday after the U.N. coordinator in Baghdad said he hoped the world body would receive by 2000 GMT Iraq's food distribution plan under an oil-for-food deal.
The six-month $2 billion plan was renewed a month ago but Iraq's oil exports have been delayed, pending completion of the government's distribution and procurement plans.
Traders also said they thought bearish predictions from the International Energy Agency (IEA) had exerted a little bearish influence.
The IEA said oil prices would fall further this year as burgeoning supply boosts stocks, despite higher-than-expected gasoline demand in the U.S.
Oil traders were also awaiting weekly U.S. oil industry data, which was expected to emerge on time on Tuesday night despite the Fourth of July holiday in the U.S.
Technical analysts said they saw first important support for Brent at around $18.05, then at $17.96.
